description: Details required by Condition 5 (Site Management) of Planning Permission 18/00117/FUL (Erection of two storey building providing 2x 1 bed units.)
decision_conditions: That the applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above are agreed and that the conditions as noted above, is fully discharged.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.Eight neighbouring properties have been notified and one letter of support has been received.Kingston Town Neighbourhood Conservation Areas Advisory Committee - No objections raised.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- The impact of the development on the Grove Crescent Conservation Area.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.   In determining planning applications which affect heritage assets, Paragraph 192 of the NPPF 2019 requires local planning authorities to take account of: the desirability of sustaining and enhancing the significance of heritage assets and putting them to viable uses consistent with their conservation; the positive contribution that conservation of heritage assets can make to sustainable communities including their economic vitality; and the desirability of new development making a positive contribution to local character and distinctiveness.                                                                                                                     Paragraph 193 of NPPF 2019 states that when considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the assets conservation, irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts of substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Core Strategy 2012 sets out the Council's commitment to preserve or enhance the existing heritage assets of the Borough through the promotion of high quality design and a focus on heritage-led regeneration. The Council will allow alterations which preserve or enhance the established character and architectural interest of a heritage asset, its fabric or its setting, and will ensure that development proposals affecting historic assets will use high quality materials and design features which incorporate or compliment those of the host building or the immediate area. Features of local importance and special interest will be respected through the consideration of form, scale, layout and detailed designs of a site, area or streetscape.                                                                                                                 Officer comment: The significance of the Grove Crescent Conservation Area is as an early residential suburb of Kingston Town Centre dating from the mid 19th century. It went through at least three distinct waves of development before becoming a local centre with a church, public house, shops and a school. It is considered that the proposed development would relate well to the main dwelling and the immediate surrounding area.  Due to the subordinate and proportionate nature of the proposals, as well materials proposed to match exisiting, the extensions and alterations  are considered to preserve the character and appearance of the Grove Crescent Conservation and would not cause any harm to the heritage asset. In conclusion, the proposed development would accord with the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended), the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2016), the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Please submit a copy of an Ordnance Survey based site location plan scaled 1:1250 with the application site outlined in red and adjoining land owned by applicant in blue, showing at least two road frontages and a North point.Please note that we do not accept Land Registry maps
